g.text: During the DJF season, the area of strongest decrease in high
cloud cover is located over the central tropical Paci
contour lines in Fig. 2d). This region of decreased tropical deep
convection coincides with the area of the largest outgoing
longwave radiation (OLR) increase (see shading in Fig. 2d). In the
second teleconnection step, decreased deep convection in the
c (Fig. 2d) and the associated decrease in upper-
level divergence force a northward-propagating Rossby wavetrain
with negative (cyclonic) anomalies in the northern tropical Paci
and positive (anticyclonic) anomalies in the extratropical North
c sector. This is evident from the 250 mb stream function
manifestation of the geopotential ridge in Fig. 2e
responsible for steering the wet winter air masses away from
California. The atmospheric anomalies in the North Paci
The convection changes described above are consistent with
the simulated upper-level vertical velocity anomalies and Hadley
circulation changes. From a climatological perspective, the
descending branch of the winter Hadley cell is positioned over
(and to the west of) California (Fig. 3a and Supplementary Fig. 6).
California, while also affecting the uplift and subsidence regions
circulation plays a key role in the atmospheric transport of heat
Hadley circulation are an expected and known dynamical
response to the energy budget perturbations shown in Supple-
The schematic in Fig. 4 summarizes the hypothesized two-step
teleconnection, involving sea-ice loss, tropical convection reorga-
nization, a northward-propagating Rossby wavetrain, and a
decrease in precipitation over California. Several previous studies
have suggested that tropical and subtropical Paci
changes affect precipitation over California by inducing geopo-
tential anomalies in the North Paci
and subtropical convection changes could be a consequence of
natural variability, our analysis indicates that they can also be
forced from the high latitudes by substantial sea-ice loss. Our
simulations imply that two hitherto separate hypotheses
can drive precipitation changes over California (
are not easily separable. Our study
demonstrates that the impacts of Arctic sea-ice changes require
understanding complex atmospheric teleconnections that can
propagate back and forth between the extratropics and the
Atmospheric impacts of Antarctic sea-ice loss
investigate the proposed two-step teleconnection, and addition-
ally verify that sea-ice-induced tropical convection changes are
forcing the circulation changes in the North Paci
the impacts of another source of remote forcing: Antarctic sea-ice
loss. Antarctic sea-ice decline will result in a warming at mid- to
high latitudes of the southern hemisphere. One consequence of
this warming is a southward shift of tropical precipitation, with
convection increase in the southern and central tropical Paci
This is the opposite to the precipitation response accompanying
Arctic sea-ice loss. In accord with previous studies
mechanism advanced here, increased convection should in turn
drive a northward-propagating Rossby wavetrain consisting of an
anticyclonic anomaly in the tropical Paci
with negative geopotential height anomalies over the North
c (geopotential low) leading to wetter conditions over
California. Simulations in which the sea-ice physics parameter
perturbations are prescribed in the Southern hemisphere only
Fig. 1b, d) show a response that is consistent with these expec-
tations. Tropical precipitation shifts southward (Fig. 5a), antic-
ow is established over the northern tropical Paci
ow is formed over the North Paci
geopotential ridge in the North Paci
c is replaced with a geo-
potential trough, favoring the propagation of tropical storms
across California (Fig. 5b). As a result, precipitation over Cali-
mechanism can be triggered by sea-ice changes in either
hemisphere. Since Antarctic sea-ice loss involves northward
propagation in both teleconnection steps (i.e., Antarctic sea-ice
c, which in turn affects the North
c) and no high northern latitude changes, it provides
additional support for our conjecture that the sea-ice changes can
convection changes. More generally, any high-latitude perturba-
tion (northern or southern hemispheric warming or cooling) that
impacts the position of the tropical Paci

control ensemble mean). Positive sign denotes subsidence. Stippling in
